texts.definition: Halts to gameplay due to one or more players spending considerable amounts of time planning or understanding the consequences of different possible actions.
markups: <style="Definition">Halts to gameplay due to one or more players spending considerable amounts of time planning or understanding the consequences of different possible actions.</style>

Players can spend considerable amounts of time planning their actions in some games. When this makes other players have to wait since gameplay cannot continue until the player has made up his or her mind, it is usually experienced as negative and referred to as <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style>. The reason for <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> may be that the number of choices is overwhelming so one does know where to start ones planning but may also be that one most of the time can see the advantage of just a bit more planning.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style> have been used as prime examples of games where there is a possibility to almost endlessly analyze possible future actions. Both have decision trees, which grow exponentially over game time.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Diplomacy">Diplomacy</link></style>, even though the possible actions are quite limited, can cause <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> when the players start to think recursively about what the other players are trying to do and how the other players would perceive the players' actions.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> manages to make all players simultaneously have <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> as they try to find the optimal solution for moving a robot from point a to point b.

<style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> can only occurs in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> that are also <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style>, and can then be more or less likely depending on the presence of other patterns. That being said, it's effect when it can occur at all is typically enhanced if <style="Link"><link="player-unpredictability">Player Unpredictability</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> exists. It is a negative pattern in the sense that avoiding to have it in a game is more often a design goal than intentionally having it. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> is however an example where the pattern is not a problem since all players are causing the time-bound <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> and one player's action forces all other players to reconsider their plans. Gameplay complexity tends to increase in <style="Link"><link="middlegame">Middlegame</link></style> phases of games and for this reason <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> is quite likely to occur then. It is also often likely to occur near the end of game instances, i.e. in <style="Link"><link="endgame">Endgame</link></style>, but for the different reasons that it might both be easier to analyze the game state then and that the stakes for making the right actions are more important.

Although <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> may occur in any game where a player has a choice and the game state is frozen until the choice is made, there are some design choices that can increase the likelihood of the pattern emerging. The primary of these are having <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style> since this lets players consider the effects of their actions. On a higher level of abstraction, <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> can be achieved by letting players have <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> in the form of a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> between several actions with <style="Link"><link="predictable-consequences">Predictable Consequences</link></style>, even if these are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> or players have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Resources">Limited Resources</link></style> (and especially so if combined with <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="action-programming">Action Programming</link></style> can produce this effect also but may then not reveal the effects until much later. This forces players to consider <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> and if the value of the effects caused are difficult to judge it may further increase the risk of <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> occurring. <style="Link"><link="action-caps">Action Caps</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="budgeted-action-points">Budgeted Action Points</link></style> provide means of expanding the number of decisions the players have to make in each decision point, in effect, broadening the scope of <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> - this does however not need to be the case if the number of possible actions are kept low so these patterns can also counter the emergence of <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style>. The use of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> is another possible source for <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> since it, besides typically adding to a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, opens up for planning of <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> (this effect of <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> is even stronger when it is combined with <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="orthogonal-differentiation">Orthogonal Differentiation</link></style>). To a lesser extent, <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> can cause <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> but this become less and less likely as players gain <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style> since the mental work associated with <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic Planning</link></style> can be reused to a greater extent than that based on <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>.

The amount of information available to players can easily affect the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perfect%20Information">Perfect Information</link></style> lets players have more information available for consideration while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Symmetric%20Information">Symmetric Information</link></style> helps players consider other players potential actions into the planning. Open <style="Link"><link="discard-piles">Discard Piles</link></style> in card games, giving players more complete <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style>, allows players to easier calculate odds for future draws and plays of cards and may thereby also cause <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style>. The use of <style="Link"><link="end-state-scoring">End State Scoring</link></style> can cause <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> in any game, but it is much more likely to do so in games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perfect%20Information">Perfect Information</link></style> since then all players can - and may feel complied to try to as part of trying to win - analyze all players positions just before the end of gameplay. Games with <style="Link"><link="solution-uncertainty">Solution Uncertainty</link></style> also causes <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style>, in this case because players know there is a solution; see <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> for a game where all players simultaneously have <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> but where this does not cause a problem since the first players to find a solution starts a bidding war by declaring that solution.

The likelihood can also be modulated by <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Set%20of%20Actions">Limited Set of Actions</link></style> of other players. This allows players to a greater degree to not only to consider the direct effects of their actions but plan a sequence of actions. <style="Link"><link="predefined-goals">Predefined Goals</link></style> may affect the likelihood of <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> occurring differently depending on how distant the goal is: goals that may easily be reached may lessen it as may distant or strategic goals while the ones in between may increase it. The presence of <style="Link"><link="internal-conflicts">Internal Conflicts</link></style> for individual players easily rises the likelihood for <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> to occur since they need to make a choice and it is non-trivial.

There are several ways of reducing the risk for <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style>. First <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> makes it impossible to maintain the <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> for longer than a certain period of time, but at the potential cost of introducing <style="Link"><link="time-pressure">Time Pressure</link></style>. One can also introduce <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> to the consequences of actions and thereby giving players <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Foresight">Limited Foresight</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Planning%20Abilities">Limited Planning Abilities</link></style>. Games with <style="Link"><link="private-game-spaces">Private Game Spaces</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Race%20for%20the%20Galaxy">Race for the Galaxy</link></style>) can mitigate the causes of the pattern since other players can easier plan simultaneously plan when their actions do to a lesser degree affect each other.

The pattern can also occur when players need to choose between goals, e.g. having to choose which <style="Link"><link="committed-goals">Committed Goal</link></style> to choose from a <style="Link"><link="selectable-set-goals">Selectable Set of Goals</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> is usually a feature game designers try to avoid in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. That players have <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> can be a sign that the game has too <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style> for those players but can also indicate a desire in the design to have <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cognitive%20Engrossment">Cognitive Engrossment</link></style>. The nature of <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> situations has a somewhat adverse effect on the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Anticipation">Anticipation</link></style> of the uncertain outcome during the play.

In games with <style="Link"><link="turn-taking">Turn Taking</link></style>, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Analysis Paralysis</style> can lead to excessive <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> when players get stuck in planning their turns, and this can in turn lead to <style="Link"><link="guilting">Guilting</link></style>. While the <style="Link"><link="downtime">Downtime</link></style> can let other players interact with each other socially, the pattern cannot be said to create <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minimized%20Social%20Weight">Minimized Social Weight</link></style> but rather the opposite since the player engrossed in his or her planning cannot be interacted with and any social interaction may disturb him or her.
